measured_by: chimeric-face procedure (left vs. right emotional halves)
justification: “Levy, Heller, Banich & Burton (1983) discuss the potential lateralization of emotional processing, using a chimeric face procedure… participants were asked to choose between two copies of chimeric faces.”

measured_by: visual search paradigm with target-present vs. target-absent displays
justification: “For the topic of Perception, the visual search paradigm and feature integration theory were introduced… it is easier to detect unknown targets defined by the presence rather than absence of a feature.”
construct: visual search asymmetry (feature presence vs. absence)

measured_by: telephone-message monitoring task with concurrent doodling
justification: “Participants were asked to monitor a telephone message… another group (dual task group) were also asked to 'doodle'… the doodle group observed to have better intentional memory of the party-goers.”
construct: dual-task benefit / cost in auditory memory

measured_by: house narrative recall task with buyer vs. burglar perspectives
justification: “Pichert & Anderson (1976)… participants were provided with a perspective… When tested… perspective-consistent information was better remembered than perspective-inconsistent information.”

measured_by: object recognition test with novel, exemplar, and state pairs
justification: “Brady et al. (2008) presented 2,896 objects… Later they showed pairs where the new object was novel, an exemplar, or the same object in a different state to assess the level of detail retained within long-term memory.”
construct: visual long-term memory capacity for object details

measured_by: trivia question learning task with no feedback vs. ‘correct/incorrect’ vs. correct-answer feedback
justification: “Pashler, Cepeda, Wixted & Rohrer (2005) examined three different classes of feedback… no feedback, the feedback of being 'correct' or 'incorrect', with the provision of the correct answer.”
construct: effects of feedback on retention of semantic information

measured_by: Rock, Paper, Scissors game tracking post-loss strategy shifts
justification: “Dyson et al. (2016) noted that the probability of changing responses is more likely after losing relative to winning a RPS round (i.e., lose-shift > win-shift).”

“From Cooper & Shepard (1973), participants were asked to categorize shapes with varying degrees of rotation, as either forwards-facing or backwards-facing letter Rs… the further a shape was rotated… the longer it should take.”
“Participants were invited to complete both the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire (VVIQ; Marks, 1973).”
